newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani cotton rates end down on higher arrivals.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani cotton rates end down on higher arrivals.

text.p: Pakistani cotton rates ended down on increased picking of raw cotton following good weather in Punjab province, which accounts for 80 percent of the crop, brokers at the private Karachi Cotton Association (KCA) said. They said rates would open lower on Thursday.
In the kerb market, the rate for 1996/97 (July-June) NIAB-78 fell to 2,350 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) from 2,450 on Tuesday, broker Haider Ali said.
Increased picking and arrivals of raw cotton at ginning factories were the main factor behind the fall, Ali said, adding: "I see a sharp fall in rates in the next few days."
He said the fact that flood damage to cotton had been negligible would keep rates under downward pressure.
The KCA said exports had reached 1.82 million 375-lb bales by August 25 since the 1995/96 season began on September 1.
KCA official spot rates in rupees per maund:
K-68 (1996/97 crop) not quoted not quoted
